coding.display: Malignant lymphoma, no International Classification of Diseases for Oncology subtype

resource.comment:
Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Rhys Evans:\\  Please note that this patient has requested that a copy of this letter is sent to them as part of the 'Copying Letters to Patients' initiative. As this is a clinical letter written from one doctor to another, it is likely to contain some technical information. If the patient does not understand any part of the letter and wishes to obtain further specific explanation about their condition, they should contact their clinician's or therapist's secretary.
I was pleased to see Karli Broadbent for review today. Unfortunately she has developed a further episode of left maxillary sinusitis following a cold this last week and she has some purulent discharge from the left side of the nose.
The palatal fistula appears to have closed very nicely following the surgery and she has no leakage now when eating and drinking. There was one episode when she was taking some tomato sauce that she got some discolouration in the nose but hopefully the fistula is now well closed oft. I have given her some Augmentin for the sinusitis and Menthol and eucalyptus inhalation.
I am seeing her again in 1 months time

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof. Cunningham:\\Diagnosis:- 1) NK Cell Lymphoma (CD3+, CD56+, TlA-1+, CD20-) affecting right nasal cavity and hard palate (diagnosed July 2001). 2) Left para-pharyngeal recess confirmed on biopsy (May 2003).
Treatment:- 1) ProMACECytoBOM x3 followed by involved field radiotherapy 50Gy followed by further ProMACECytoBOM x3 (completed Feb 2002) to complete response. 2) Recurrence treated with Gem-P x2 and intrathecal Methotrexate x3 (Jul-Sep 2003) followed by stem cell harvest. 3). High dose chemotherapy (Melphalan/Etoposide) January 2004.
Karli attended clinic today. The MRI shows no clear evidence of recurrent disease. There is persistent soft tissue thickening which is thought to be due to inflammatory change. In any  event we will keep this area under constant review and the MRI will be repeated in January along with a whole body scan

Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Rhys Evans::\\Diagnosis: Aug 01 NIK T cell lymphoma (midline granuloma arising from the floor of the nasopharynx and hard palate)
Treatment. Chemo-radiation completed Feb 02. July 03 palatal fistula near midline biopsy showed recurrent tumour.
Treatment. further chemotherapy completed Feb 04
I was pleased to see Karli Broadbent for review today and have removed her palatal pack. The fistula has closed over completely but the recent scan has confirmed that she has bilateral maxillary sinusitis. I am sure the sinusitis is secondary to the fact that food debris has been going into the nose over a long period of time infecting the sinuses. I hope that it will settle down now that the fistula has closed. I am seeing her in 2 months time and if she still has a purulent postnasal discharge I will arrange to carry out antral washouts

Episode type: Other, Free text: T-cell lymphoma (mid-line granuloma causing palatal fistula) Repair of palatal fistula and removal of Hickman line Recovery
Uneventful Followup With Mr. Rhys-Evans in a week's time

Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Evans:\\I was pleased to see Karli for review today. The infection seems to have cleared up in the nose and hopefully there has been no further discharge from the oral cavity into the nose. Her reconstructed area looks very good under the flap and I think it would be a good idea to keep this for another 2 weeks before we do anything to remove the dressing

Free text: Routine culture
  Scanty growth of Coagulase neg. Staphylococcus
   This is skin flora.
 
  No primary pathogens isolated
Cuff size used: Standard, Posture for BP recording: Sitting
Cuff size used: Standard, Posture for BP recording: Sitting
Episode type: First ever, Free text: left eye, very tender and visibly reg tearduct, so swab taken and start Rx
Episode type: First ever, Free text: more nasal blockage recently and left eye now sore red, tearful and with some sticky discharge

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Rhys-Evans:\\I saw Karli for review today. The small palatal fistula is much the same size as before and gives rise to occasional problems with leakage. I doubt whether it will close up any more on it's own and have said htat I would be very happy to arrange for her to come in to have it closed with a local flap.
She did mention that she does have a permacath in place for blood tests and that this is going to be removed at some stage. It might be possible if she wants a palatal operation done to remove the permacath at the same time.
I understand she is seeing you again next week and have asked her to get in touch with me following her visit to you

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof. Cunningham:\\Diagnosis: Aug 01 N/K T cell lymphoma (midline granuloma arising from the floor of the nasopharynx and hard palate)
Treatment: Chemo-radiation completed Feb 02. July 03 palatal fistula near midline biopsy showed re rrent tumour. Treatment: further chemotherapy completed Feb 04
Karli attended for review today. In general she is well. The MRI shows no definite evidence of recurrent disease although there is some increase in tissue which is thought to be inflammatory in origin. This would be accounted for by the persistent defect in the soft palate. Karli would like to have the defect repaired but is not sure if she wants to leave it for a few months In any event I would plan to repeat the MRI in 3 months time. Meanwhile, unless she is going ahead with the repair in the short-term, I have advised that we have the central line removed

Episode type: Other, Free text: Jobcentre plus:\\Payment of Incapacity Benefits and the award of National Insurance credits are subject to an incapacity assessment. If a person meets, or is treated as meeting, the threshold of incapacity, medical certificates are no longer needed to support their claim.
As the patient shown above meets or is treated as meeting the threshold of incapacity under the Personal Capability Assessment you no longer need to issue NHS medical certificates for this person's claim for benefit. However, we may need to contact you for further information about your patient's incapacity in the future.
Proof of incapacity or illness may still be required for other interested groups or organisations such as employers and insurance companies. The provision of this information is not usually an NHS requirement.
If your patient makes another claim for benefit in the future, we will require medical certificates from the date of incapacity. The booklet IB204 'A guide for registered medical practitioners' gives more information. If you do not have this booklet, you can get it from your local Jobcentre Plus/social security office. It is also published on the DSS website at www.dwp.gov.uk/hq/pubs/medical
If you want to ask us anything about this letter, please get in touch with us. Our phone number and address are at the top of this letter

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Samantha Peacock,  Chartered Clinical Psychologist:\\I was pleased to review Karli today in the Department of Psychological Medicine. Overall Karli appears to be managing well. She has some underlying worries regarding her long-term prognosis and the possibility of her cancer returning, however, she feels that this is not interfering with her daily life and is manageable at the present time. I have reiterated with Karli that these are appropriate worries for her to have, and we just need to closely monitor how Karli adjusts over time.
Karli anticipates feeling worried about her forthcoming scan in June, and I have encouraged her to contact me if she wishes for additional support then. Karli intends to return to art college in September and we have discussed the impact of trying to have some daily structure and activities to engage her over the next few months. Karli tends to cope better and worry much less when distracted, and she needs to keep a close eye on her levels of boredom and socialising. She is aware of this.
Karli has agreed to contact me nearer to her scan, and we can meet again if she considers this necessary.
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any queries or concerns

Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Evans:\\  Diagnosis: Aug 01 N/K T cell lymphoma (midline granuloma arising from the floor of the nasopharynx and hard palate) Treatment: Chemo-radiation completed Feb 02 July 03 palatal fistula near midline - biopsy showed recurrent tumour Treatment: further chemotherapy completed Feb 04
Thank you very much indeed for kindly asking me to see Karli again. Since she completed the treatment the small palatal midline fistula has gradually closed. She is however getting some nasal escape and when she drinks fluid some does come through the fistula into the nose. She has some degree of hyper-nasal speech.
On examination the fistula is at the junction of the soft and hard palate, just to the right of the midline and is about 2mms in diameter. She also has some retraction of the soft palate and she is probably getting some nasal air escape through the velo-pharyngeal aperture as well as through the fistula.
On fibreoptic rhinoscopy, the posterior part of the septum has been lost through the tumour and there is a corresponding defect about 2 - 3 mms in diameter in the nasal floor.
There is no sign of any recurrence and the nasal adhesions which I divided last June have not reformed and she is breathing quite well through the nose.
It is quite possible that the small fistula will continue to close and I have advised that we should just keep this under review in the first instance as it is not causing any significant symptom. I am seeing her again in 2 months time and if it does persist and continue to cause problems I will arrange to admit her to carry out a local palatal flap closure of the defect

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof. Cunninghamn:\\1 am delighted to report that Karli's most recent MRI of the head and neck and whole body CT scan shows no evidence of recurrent disease. We were planning to consider maintenance CAMP)A for 3 months. On reflection, given the excellent response to treatment and the unproven benefits  from CAMPATH in this setting, coupled with the risks associated with therapy, I have recommended we adopt a watch and wait policy with a repeat MRI scan in 3 months in addition, I have made a referral to my colleague Peter Rhys-Evans for his eva luation of the nasopharynx with a view to consideration of closing the defect in the soft palate

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof.Cunningham:\\Karli has made an excellent recovery from high dose chemotherapy administered in January of this year I have organised a whole body CT scan and an MRI scan of the head and neck, to ascert in the current disease status. We discussed maintenance treatment with CAMPATH for a period of 12 weeks, beginning approximately 3 months after high dose chemno erap 1. Karli and her family will come back to discuss this in a few weeks time

Episode type: Other, Free text: DR Waters:\\DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Date Admitted 7 Jan 2004
Date Discharged 3 Feb 2004 Diagnosis NK-T cell non Hodgkin's Lymphoma Previous treatment: 2001 PROMACE CytaBOM X 3 cycles followed by involved field radiotherapy to 50Gy in 25#, followed by a further three cycles of PROMACE CytaBOM with treatment completed in February 2002. Relapsed in May 2003 treated with Gem-P x 2 cycles, plus intrathecal Methotrexate. HISTORY Reason for admission: High dose chemotherapy with Melphalan and Etoposide followed by autolagus peripheral stem cell re-infusion.
Further to our previous correspondence Karli was admitted for the above treatment. At the time for admission she was well and performance status was 0. She had a good appetite and her weight was stable. She had mild runny nose but no evidence of local relapse of her disease. Her portacath was in situ with no evidence of local infection. Her medication comprised Norethisterone, 5mg tds and she had no known allergies. Examination findings were entirely satisfactory. Karli's pre-high dose therapy investigations were as follows: GFR 76ml per minute measured by EDTA. Left ventricular ejection fraction 60% and 62% on two separate measurements with reasonable regional left ventricular wall motion. Lung function impaired with TLCOC 62.4% of predicted value therefore BCNU omitted from conditioning regimen. CD-34 + cell harvest 1.84 x 106 per kg.
Karli had received detailed information on the high dose chemotherapy procedure including explanation of the risks involved. She provided written consent to proceed with this. Her high dose chemotherapy was given without immediate complication and her stem cells were returned on 14 th and 15 th January 2004. She became neutropenic on 17 th January and started to develop some oral mucositis at this point. She also became febrile and was commenced on first line antibiotics with Tazocin and Gentamicin with the addition ofTeicoplanin in view of her indwelling permacath. She was also given standard mouthcare.
Over the next few days she continued to spike fevers and had standard manipulations in her intravenous antibiotics. She developed diarrhoea and her oral mucositis became more severe requiring analgesia with a diamorphine infusion. She required the addition of intravenous antifungal treatment with Voriconazole due to a persistent fever although all blood and urine cultures were negative. Her white cell count started to improve on 22 nd January and she wascommenced on GCSF to hasten neutrophil recovery. By the 26 th January her temperaturewas settling and her condition was improving generally. Her diarrhoea stopped and her oralmucositis began to heal. We were able to change her intravenous antibiotics to oralantibiotics on 28 Ih January with no further increase in her temperature and with theimprovement of her oral mucositis we were able to wean her intravenous diamorphine. Bythe 3' February she was feeling much better and was maintaining a good oral intake of fluidand diet. Her blood count at this point was haemoglobin of 12.0, wbc 3.5, platelets 71 andneutrophils 1.5 and she was therefore allowed home with plans for review with a full blood count check, on 6 th February. She will be seen at weekly intervals for the first month and will be seen by  sor Cunningham in four week's time in the outpatient clinic

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Kulkarni:\\Karli is coming in today for her chemotherapy plus G-CSF mobilisation. She has got a Permacath that can be used for her harvest. We have discussed Karli's case with David and the consensus of opinion was that she would be better off having Cyclophosphamide 2g /M2 as a single dose which will be done today with Mesna rescue and G-CSF starting tomorrow in the dose of 10/ig/kg subcut once a day. We will measure her peripheral CD34 on Day 5 but unfortunately that comes on Saturday so she will have it done on Day 4 which is on Friday and based on those results we will decide the date of her harvest. It is a possibility that we might not get enough stem cells even with chemotherapy plus G-CSF and definitely as David wants to give 4 weeks between her chemo mobilisation and transplant, the transplant will happen in the new year and hopefully in the first week. It is possible that we will have to do Karli's harvest on 3 or 4 occasions and I would prefer that to happen if we get a good yield. Episode type: Other, Free text: Professor Cunngingham:\\1 am pleased to report that Karli's MRI taken after 2 cycles of chemotherapy has shown a sustained response to treatment. There has been no further incremental change in the appearances on MR so I have therefore decided to proceed directly to high dose chemotherapy. With regard to Campath, currently we are considering using it after high dose chemotherapy. Meanwhile I have organised the peripheral blood stem cell transplantation. Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Waters:\\Karli has been tolerating chemotherapy well so far. Her only side-effect has been a papular rash over the back and chest which was initially pruritic and possibly acnea form but at the time of admission was fading. Her full blood count was satisfactory and she proceeded with chemotherapy as planned. Of note, there is an elevation of her ALT to 254 and a repeat estimation on 23' September has gone up to 303. This may be a side-effect of Gemcitabine and we will obviously need to monitor this before proceeding with her next dose of treatment. She is now due a week off treatment and will be seen in 2 weeks

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Alfulaij:\\DiagnosisNK/T-cell lymphoma - nasal type - relapsed
Karli came to Robert Tiffany ward for day 8 of cycle 1 Gemcitabine and received her second dose of intrathecal methotrexate. After day 1 of her first cycle she had 24 hours of diarrhoea which resolved spontaneously. She was also feeling extremely tired for 7 days and experienced some epigastric burning pain. Her appetite remains good and she is eating well. Clinical examination was unremarkable and her blood results were satisfactory so she proceeded with chemotherapy

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Peacock:\\I am writing to update you of my involvement with the above young lady, whom I have been offering therapeutic support to since last October. Karli was initially referred to me by Dr Mary Taj in the Paediatric Unit with concerns regarding her level of fatigue and anxiety. I have been meeting with Karli on a regular basis over the last 10 months or so, and we have been offering her support in terms of managing some of the side effects of her treatment and coping with uncertainty regarding her health. Karli has experienced a persistent feeling of fatigue and a fluctuating low mood, and she has experienced considerable worry with regard to the possibility of relapsing, and this degree of anxiety has certainly impacted in a detrimental fashion upon her quality of life. Despite this, Karli has been able to complete her A-Level examinations and she has a College placement awaiting her in September.
I was able to meet today with Karli and her mother on Robert Tiffany Ward, which has been the first time since the unfortunate news that she has relapsed and requires further treatment. Despite her tendency to put on a coping front, Karli was tearful and anxious today and she appeared to be struggling to manage. She appears to have lost more weight over the last month, and she looked tired and presented as withdrawn, with a flat affect. She admits finding the current situation somewhat overwhelming and she is also having to cope with the transition from the Paediatric Unit to adult care within the hospital. She is having to get used to a new ward, new doctors and nurses, and unfamiliar surroundings and in addition, she reports having been anxious regarding medical procedures, particularly needles. I understand that she has experienced some difficulties with lumbar punctures, and she was extremely anxious regarding this procedure this afternoon. Karli has lots of underlying worries regarding her treatment, and she is concerned at the prospect of high-dose chemotherapy and a transplant, which I believe have been discussed with the family. I understand that Karli has been tearful at home, and has been feeling tired and de-motivated, and fatigue has been one of Karli's main side effects from her previous treatment.
It appears that Karli coped with the news of her relapse extremely well on the surface, however, she has been struggling to manage more recently. Her current feelings and worries are entirely appropriate given the recent news of her relapse and the significant adjustments that the family have had to make, and I have attempted to normalise how she is feeling at the present time. Much of my work to date with Karli has focussed on exploring the links between her mood, her underlying worries and her level of activity and the potentially detrimental influence of her fatigue upon her mood and what she is able to do. It will be important that Karli's mood is closely monitored as there is a tendency for her to withdraw and lose interest in things that she enjoys which can be a vicious cycle, and her mother is also concerned that she is losing her 'fighting spirit'. Karli's mother is keen to take one step at a time and to just look towards her daughter's scan at the end of her first cycle of chemotherapy. Unfortunately, Karli felt that she had made good progress in terms of how she was feeling and she was looking forward to attending College at the start of September. It has always been difficult for Karli to retain some sense of normality as a teenager, and it seems that she has many underlying anxieties regarding the future.
I will continue to offer therapeutic support to Karli, and I will also be liaising with the Sargent Social Work Team to ascertain if there are ways in which the rest of the family can be supported from a psycho-social perspective. Nursing staff have also found Karli to be more withdrawn today compared to last week, and it will be important that her mood is closely monitored. I understand that she experienced difficulties this afternoon with her lumbar puncture, and she remains anxious about medical procedures. I have agreed to see Karli next week when she attends for her next course of chemotherapy, and I have asked for my contact details to be placed in the nursing notes.
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or concerns. I will keep you informed of further progress with Karli, and I will continue to offer support to the family

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof. Cunningham:\\It was an absolute pleasure to meet Karli who has commenced GEM-P chemotherapy for relapsed NK- T cell lymphoma. The plan is to treat her with this regimen for between 2 and 4 cycles, and then consolidate with intensive treatment. The other option which I think we may wish to consider is using CAM PATH if the cells express CD-52. I have arranged for a scan to b erformed following one cycle of GEM-P and then I will see Karli back in the clinic, togethe wi h the result

Karli came to Robert Tiffany ward today for insertion of a Picc line and commencement of the first cycle of chemotherapy with Gemcitabine and Cisplatin. I saw her with Dr Paul Ross on Robert Tiffany ward to explain to her the plan of treatment which will include systemic chemotherapy with Gemcitabine and Cisplatin as a part of the trial. Karli was consented for the trial after all appropriate investigations confirmed her eligibility and a Picc line was inserted and she proceeded with day 1 of Gemcitabine.
Unfortunately there was difficulty in giving her intrathecal under local anaesthetic and she was very anxious so I have arranged for her this to be done on HDU tomorrow under sedation. Karli will have her day 8 of Gemcitabine next Thursday but she will be seen by Professor Cunningham on 51h August

Episode type: Other, Free text: Prof. Cunningham:\\'H EIC No: 185 7
A phase H study of Gemcitabine, Methylprednisolone and Cisplatin (GEM-P) in
,patients with relapsed or refractory lymphoma
Your patient has relapsed or refractory lymphoma and has agreed to participate in a study evaluating combination chemotherapy with gemcitabine, methylprednisolone and cisplatin in this disease.
The potential side effects of these chemotherapeutic agents are:
15 Bone marrow suppression (anaemia, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia)
16 Nausea and vomiting
17 Flu-like symptoms
18 Alopecia
19 Renal impairment
20 Oedema
21 Tinnitus and hearing loss
Your patient will be monitored closely for all side effects and dose adjustments and additional medications given as appropriate. The treatment is given with curative intent for up to 6 months, depending on response.
Should your patient run into any problems with this treatment, I would be grateful if you could communicate these to my Senior Registrar or the out of hours equivalent at the Royal Marsden Hospital on 0208 642 6011. We will keep you closely informed of the patient's progress, and if you should require any further information, please do not hesitate to enquire

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Ross:\\Thank you for kindly asking me to take over the care of this 19 year old girl whose history you summarised in your referral letter. As you are aware, her current symptoms are blockage of the right side of her nose with a post-nasal drip causing a slight cough first thing in the morning. She lost about half a stone in the spring when she had an ear infection but her weight has been stable since then. She has no B symptoms.
On examination today she has no palpable lymphadenopathy. Cardiovascular, respiratory and abdominal examinations were unremarkable.
I spoke to Karli accompanied by her parents, her brother Jo and Michelle Pollard, Research Nurse for Lymphoma. I explained that she would need to be re-staged prior to treatment with a repeat MR[ of the face, CT scan, bone marrow aspirate and trephine, blood count and biochemistry. I further explained that the overall treatment plan would be induction with chemotherapy and if a complete remission is achieved we would subsequently proceed to high dose chemotherapy with stem cell support. We discussed the combination of Gemcitabine Cisplatin and Methylprednisolone (GEM-P) and outlined the administration schedule and its potential side effects. She has been supplied with an information sheet on this today.
Mrs Broadbent raised the subject of egg storage particularly as they are aware that high dose chemotherapy would result in sterility. We explained that while this is feasible unfertilised ovum storage or ovarian tissue storage remains an experimental technique. I further explained that this may result in a delay of six to eight weeks in starting treatment and that during this period her lymphoma will continue to progress. Her treatment will be delivered via a peripherally inserted cannula (PICC line) to overcome the problems of venous access. Many thanks once again for your kind referral

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Taj:\\ Karli came to clinic today for discussion of the result of the biopsy of her para-pharyngeal mass. I explained that she had unfortunately relapsed, with both her left naso-pharyngeal biopsy and right maxillary sinus biopsy showing evidence of recurrent nasal T-NK cell lymphoma. She was very stoical about this and said that she had suspected that she probably had relapsed because she had developed further symptoms of hoarseness of voice, blocked nose and ears.
Since Karli is 19 years old she agreed that she had to be transferred to the adult physicians. We discussed the various pros & cons of either remaining at The Marsden, a place she is familiar with, or going to the central Middlesex Hospital where they have an adolescent unit.
On balance she decided to stay at The Marsden, and I have referred her to Dr Paul Ross for further treatment.
I called Paul and told him that Karli is aware that her overal ' I prognosis is very bad, but that further treatment with possibly ano autologous transplant.Cshould she show response) was
the treatment plan

Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Kirkland:\\ Thank you for referring this patient to Mr Rhys-Evans. This young lady who was diagnosed in August 2001 with lymphoma of the nasal cavity, presents with an oronasal fistula and a 3 cm mass in the left para-pharyngeal region. She is currently suffering from infected right sided rhinorrhoea.
On examination grommets were in patent and in situ in both tympanic membranes. There were no palpable neck masses. Examination of the oral cavity revealed a small fistula at the junction of the hard and soft palate. A fibreoptic nasendoscopy was not possible due to marked crusting in the right nasal cavity and nasal adhesion on the left. Unfortunately the MRI scan is not available today. I prescribed a course of Augmentin and Otrivine nose drops, and arranged to review her in the combined head and neck clinic next week at the Fulham Road branch

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Mary Taj:  \\Diagnosis:  NK T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril and soft palate.
Treatment:  ProMACE CytaBOM 6 course + radiotherapy 50gy 25#. Oral naso-fistula developed April 2003.
Weight:  40.8kg.
BP:  118/77.
Karli came to the clinic on the 9th June. She still has a nasal drip and symptoms of blocked nose but was feeling much better in herself. She currently gets less tired than before and is eating a bit better. On examination she had a well defined smooth edged fistula about 2 -3mm in size on the edge of her hard palate. Eating and drinking is a problem because liquids go through, as does soft food, like scrambled eggs and biscuits. There were no lymph nodes palpable. Examination of her nostrils showed slight redness in both anterior nares.
I explained about the presence of mass in her nasal pharynx seen on her recent MRI. The plan is to refer her to Mr Rhys-Evans at Fulham Road to have the mass biopsied. She is aware that if that proves to be a recurrence of her lymphoma she will have to be treated on the adult ward. If it turns out to be involved tissue enlargement secondary to chronic sinusitis/rhinitis then further management of her fistula and ear, nose and throat problems will be carried out by Mr Rhys-Evans. I will see her again once we have the result of her biopsy

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Mary Taj:  \\Karli had an MRI scan of her head and neck on the 2 glh May 2003. This has shown a 3 x 2.5cm mass in the parapharyngeal recess. This was not present on her previous scan done on the 31.05.02. She also has mucosal thickening in both maxillary antra. I have discussed the scans with Dr Dave McVicar who thinks that the parapharyngeal mass could be a malignant lesion. Biopsy of her oral naso-fistula has been reviewed by Dr Andy Witherspoon. It is a very small biopsy sample but shows no evidence of malignancy.
My plan is to see Karli in the clinic on ogth June 2003 and to refer her to Mr Rhys-Evans, the surgeon at Fulham Road for biopsy of this new lesion and further treatment of her oral nasofistula

Episode type: Other, Free text: Mr Brookes:\\ I reviewed Karli Broadbent in my clinic today. The histology from her recent biopsy showed inflammatory disease without any evidence of malignancy I have asked John Bullman, the Plastic Surgeon at Queen Victoria Hospital who looks after cleft palates to have a look at Karli because of her oronasal fistula and I am sure they will let us know what happens

Episode type: Other, Free text: Dr Samantha Peacock, Child and Adolescent Clinical Psychologist (to school):\\I am a Clinical Psychologist working at The Royal Marsden Hospital, and I have been offering therapeutic support to the above young lady since last October. As you will be aware, Karli was diagnosed as having a lymphoma arising from the mucosa of her right lower nostril and soft palate (a childhood cancer) and she was treated with intensive chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy. She finished treatment just over a year ago, and we have been offering her support in terms of managing some of the side effects of her treatment and coping with uncertainty regarding her health.
I am aware that Karli is due to be sitting her A level examinations over the next couple of months, and whilst she is adamant that she does not wish for special concessions of any sort for her examinations, I feel that it is important to bear in mind that Karli has been through a difficult time with her diagnosis and treatment during the course of her A levels, and she has also experienced significant tiredness and has been absent from college on a number of occasions due to feeling unwell and hospital appointments. Karli has in fact been poorly of late, and she has had surgery to fit a grommet and has also had a biopsy this week to determine if her cancer has come back. Karli is due to receive the results of her biopsy midway through her art A level practical examination, and I feel that it will be important for the college and the examination board to be aware of these stressful circumstances. Karli has been somewhat reluctant to openly discuss at college the stressful events that she has experienced over the last couple of weeks, and she is in fact managing extremely well as her examinations are helpful in distracting her from worrying. However, I have met with Karli and her mother today and we feel that it is important that there is increased awareness of Karli's current circumstances with regards to her health, and it will be important to bear in mind that she will be receiving the results of her biopsy during the height of her A level examinations. It is of course difficult to predict how Karli will feel depending on the results of her biopsy, and hence we are unable to say what Impact this will have on her examinations.
Please do not hesitate to contact me on the above telephone number if you wish to discuss this further. I also feel that it needs to be up to Karli and yourself, as her tutor, to decide whether the above information should be fed back to the relevant Examination Board. Karli does have some worries about her business study examination, as she feels that she has missed a considerable amount of the syllabus, and we have been able to spend some time discussing coping strategies for revision and ways of organising herself. However, I feel that it is important that you are aware of the above circumstances at this early stage, especially since I feel that Karli is under considerable pressure at this time.
I hope that Karli is able to do well in her examinations, and I am sure that her determination and conscientious nature will stand her in good stead

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Taj:\\ Diagnosis:      N/K T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril and     soft palate.
Treatment:      ProMACE CytaBOM (6 courses) + radiotherapy: 50 Gy in 25 fractions.
eight: 41. Kg. BP:97/53. Pulse: 74/min.
Karli attended clinic today for her regular three monthly follow-up. She still feels tired and about three weeks ago developed an ear infection which lasted two weeks requiring two courses of antibiotics. It was accompanied by fever and loss of appetite and Karli ended up missing two weeks of college. She has also lost about 7 lbs in weight but since her infection has got better, her appetite seems to have returned. She says that her left ear appears blocked, and she cannot hear very well on that side. However, she does have an appointment to see Mr Brookes, ENT surgeon, in early April.
At the time of her infection she also had a CXR done which has been reported to be normal. Her Hb was 10. 1 , and she is currently on oral iron. She continues to have a runny nose and a post-nasal drip, but according to Karli, it is a little bit better than it has been.
Her clinical examination was unchanged. Her right nostril is still crusted and the left showed some ulceration which has been present for over a year. Her hard palate showed no ulceration.
Karli's mood was much better than it has been and she continues to see Sam Peacock. Her ongoing problems are related to her ear/nose/ and throat. Given the longstanding nature of her symptoms, my feeling is that she has some sort of allergic rhinitis/sinusitis. It will be interesting to get Mr Brookes's opinion as to her recent ear infection, and hearing difficulty in the left ear. I will see Karli in three months time

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Peacock:\\ I am writing to update you of my involvement with Karli and her family, with whom I have been working on a regular basis. Karli continues to present with a persistent feeling of tiredness and a fluctuating low mood. While she has been able to pace herself somewhat in terms of her work and physical demands, she continues to report feeling extremely tired at times and she has been suffering with a persistent cold and runny nose. This particularly worries Karli and her mother, as I believe that problems such as these were present when she was first diagnosed. Karli does experience considerable worry with regard to the possibility of relapsing, and this degree of anxiety has certainly impacted in a detrimental fashion upon her current quality of life.
I met with Karli and her mother last week (14.2.03), and we were able to spend some time considering the current influence of her negative and catastrophic thinking upon the way she feels and her wellbeing. Karli's primary concerns surround the possibility of relapse, and she also struggles with her hair loss and her lack of socialising. It has been extremely difficult for Karli to regain a sense of normality following her treatment, and whilst she continues with her college education, she wishes to build upon her confidence, her level of activities and socialising. There are times, however, when Karli does not feel motivated to change, and there is a tendency for her to be preoccupied with her tiredness, which of course can be a vicious cycle. We have been able to explore the potential links between Karli's thoughts, feelings and behaviour, and whilst we should not dismiss or minimalise Karli's worries surrounding relapse in any way, it will be important for her to consider the impact of this upon her current wellbeing.
Karli has recently been offered a place on an art foundation course for September, and she is pleased about there being some direction to her future education. We have been able to discuss ways in which Karli could increase her level of socialising, although this has been met with some resistance and Karli is a shy girl who is lacking in confidence and is rather dependent on her mother. I have made attempts to introduce Karli to the Youth Cancer Trust and their specialised activity weeks, and Karli is also keen to introduce herself to another one of our female adolescent patients.
There has been some recent realisation on behalf of both Karli and her mother that she has struggled to move on from her diagnosis and treatment. Karli has acknowledged that she in control of this to a certain extent, and the work that we envisage over the next few months will focus on empowering Karli to build upon her level of confidence, her level of independence and her socialising. Karli is keen to address these difficulties, and it will be important for us to explore ways in which she can manage her worries about relapse given the constant reminders which she finds difficult (i.e. her hair, her level of tiredness, her runny nose and persistent colds). Karli does find some security in identifying herself with the hospital community here, and it is understandable that it will be difficult for her to move on, particularly given the adolescent demands that she currently faces. I will continue to meet with Karli on a regular basis, and hope that her recent motivation and realisation of the impact of her difficulties will spur her towards change. I will keep you informed of any progress, and I believe that Karli and tier mother will be keen to discuss her levels of fatigue and persistent colds with you during their next clinic appointment

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Taj:\\ Thank you for your referral of the above young lady, with concerns about her mood and general well-being. Karli was diagnosed as having an NK T-Cell Lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril and soft palate. She was treated with intensive chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy and finished treatment in February 2002.
Karli attended with her mother yesterday (17.10.02) for an initial assessment in Psychological Medicine. She presented as an intelligent, quiet young lady who was engaged and able to discuss her current difficulties in an open manner.
Karli's main concerns surround her difficulties socialising, a persistent feeling of tiredness and a fluctuating low mood. She is particularly worried that her life has not returned to the way it was prior to her illness and treatment, and she feels that she lacks confidence and independence for her age. Premorbidly, I understand that Karli was an active and sociable teenager who was frequently out with her friends. She describes feeling 'abandoned' by her friends, and whilst she has been able to return to college and attend her dance classes, it is apparent that she would like to build upon her confidence, her level of activities and socialising, at the same time as balancing her feelings of tiredness.
Karli does have some coping strategies for managing times when her mood is low, although it is not always clear what triggers a deterioration in how she feels. She has found it difficult to return to college from a social perspective, and she is clearly struggling to achieve the independence that she desires as a teenager given the health-related difficulties that she has experienced. There is some concern on behalf of Karli and her mother that she may relapse, and these concerns are exacerbated as she continues to experience colds and problems with her nose.
 Karli does have some short-term goals that she would like to pursue. She is keen to complete her college studies, despite finding it hard to concentrate, and she is motivated to build her confidence which is likely to have a subsequent effect on her level of independence and her socialising. I have asked Karli to keep a diary of activities and to rate her level of fatigue, as I am not sure that there is a balance as yet, and we will assess this further.
I will meet with Karli again on Tuesday 29' October and will keep you informed of any progress. My opinion is that Karli is a motivated young lady who is keen to work psychologically in order to restore her confidence, her level of independence and her selfidentity. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you wish to discuss the case further

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Mr Brookes:\\I was asked to see Karti Broadbent by her parents. She had a recent cold which led to a runny nose and a right glue ear. In view of her previous diagnosis of a lymphoma the parents were understandably concerned that there had been a recurrence of the original disease.
On examination today her nose appeared to be clear of disease and I examined her with the nasendoscope and her post-nasal speace amd anterior nares were all completely clear and her avacartlidge and external nodes were also normal. Her neck was clear of nodes and masses. Overall she has had a superb result from her treatment and I have reassured Mr & Mrs Broadbent that all is well

resource.comment:
Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Taj:\\Diagnosis:      NK T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril and Soft palate.
Treatment:ProMACE CytaBOM followed by radiotherapy (50 Gy in 25#).
Karli came to clinic on 30th September for her regular follow-up. She says she feels tired all the time, (although some days are better than others), and at times wakes up with a heavy feeling in the morning. She says she now sleeps better but in the past has had problems sleeping. Mum is somewhat concerned that Karli may be depressed. She has gone back to college and has dropped one of three subjects she had taken initially because she felt she could not keep up. I offered to refer her to Dr Sam Peacock and Karli is happy for me to do that.
In addition, she also has a constantly runny nose which at times becomes infected. Recently she also developed symptoms of sinusitis and a blocked right ear and has just finished a course of antibiotics which does not seem to have helped. I have asked her to see an ENT surgeon since the symptoms seem most like allergic rhinitis with super-added infection. I have explained that neither radiotherapy nor chemotherapy completely explain the symptoms she is experiencing.
On examination Karli had a mildly inflamed, red mucosa in the front part of her left nostril. It was no longer crusted. Her mouth was normal, no cervical lymph nodes were palpable and the rest of her examination was completely normal.
I explained to Karli that the cause of her tiredness was likely to be multifactorial. She is probably anxious about her future and, because she is continuing to have nasal problems, is constantly reminded that things have not gone back completely to normal. I suggested that in addition to simple measures like making sure she has 8-9 hours sleep, taking a nap in the afternoon and a paracetamol when she felt heavy-headed, she should also discuss what she has been through and what she is going through now with Dr Peacock

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: DR MARY TAJ,CONSULTANT PAEDIATRIC ONCOLOGIST.:\
Diagnosis:      N/K T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril and soft palate.
Treatment: ProMACE CytaBOM followed by radiotherapy: 50 Gy in 25#.
Karli came to clinic today for her regular appointment. The ulcerating lesion present in her left nostril looked a little bit better, although there was still a raw area there. She continues to have a runny nose but says that it is a little bit better. She has been using Perspirex for excessive sweating and says that this has significantly improved. The rest of her clinical examination was entirely normal.
I will see Karli again in six weeks. In one months time she will be due booster doses of her vaccinations (enclosed is a copy of the vaccination schedule)

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: DR MARY TAJ :\\Karli came to clinic on 15.7.02 for a routine three monthly follow-up. She continues to have a runny nose, although now her nose is not blocked. She also complains of sweating excessively and feels drenched, particularly in her armpits, even when the weather is not too hot. This has been present for some time and it seems that she has always sweated excessively although, according to Karli, it might have increased somewhat since she has been treated for her lymphoma. There is no history of temperatures or continuing weight loss. She feels much better in herself and has more energy.
Karli's MRI scan of the head done on 31.5.02 was entirely normal. On clinical examination she had a small crusted, raw lesion in her left nostril, which was entirely painless. Her palate was absolutely normal. There was no cervical lymphadenopathy.
I explained to Karli that this raw area was probably due to a continuing runny nose, or this could be due to radiotherapy. However, since in appearance it looked similar to the lesion she has had before, I will see her in about six weeks' time. If the lesion increases rapidly in size, or becomes symptomatic, she should make an earlier appointment.
As part of her chemotherapy Karli received a total anthracycline dose of 150 mgs/m2, Bleomycin 30 mgs/m2 and Cyclophosphamide 3,900 mg/m2. As far as long-term side-effects are concerned, these are not very high doses. However, just to make sure that she has no lasting effect on her heart or lungs, I will arrange for Karli to have an echocardiogram at the time of her next clinic visit, and lung function tests later this year, after her next clinic visit.
The  total dose of Cyclophosphamide was less than 4 grams/m2, so the effect on fertility should be minimal

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Mary Taj:  \\Karli came to clinic today. She was very well in herself and had no problems to report. She is feeling better and is starting to put on weight. Her current weight is 44.4 Kg having been 42.4 about two months ago. She also has had no more 'out of body' experiences, when she felt distance objects getting smaller and going away from her. She continues to have a runny nose but no headaches. Her end of chemotherapy CT & MR[ were both normal. There was some thickening of the inferior turbinate and mucosal thickening in the maxillary antrum, but no evidence of tumour.
Her clinical examination was entirely normal. She has regular menses. There was a complaint of early morning puffiness, which has been present on and off for the last six weeks, so the plan is to check her U's &E's, calcium and magnesium to check that they are alright. I will see her again in three months time for her next follow up.
I have explained to Karli and her mum that having received such intensive treatment, should the disease recur locally, there would not be a lot we could do to treat the tumour, although we will examine all possibilities if it does happen. However, the tumour has shown such a good response that the hope is that it will not recur. In the meantime the plan is to follow Karli clinically every three months

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Mary Taj:  \\This is just to let you know that Karli's electrolytes were absolutely normal and there was no evidence of kidney dysfunction.
It was indeed a pleasure to see you all, and I am glad that Karli is doing so well

8.10.01 3 x ProMACE CytaBOM (CR)
10.1 1 .01 Radical radiotherapy (50 Gy in 25 fractions)
Since 3.12.01 1 /3 of ProMCE CytaBOM.
Karli came up to the hospital today for some further chemotherapy but unfortunately, this has been deferred because of a low white cell count. I am pleased to say that the acute radiation reaction has settled very well. The skin of her face and neck remain a little dry and she is using E45 cream. The mucosa of the right nostril is also quite dry and again she continues to use E45. Her taste is returning and there is no other toxicity following the treatment. She will be rebooked for chemotherapy next week, and she tells me that she has two further doses to go. We will ensure that her further follow up appointments are arranged when she attends for her final chemotherapy

resource.comment:
Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Saran:\\ Diagnosis:      NK T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the R lower nostril
      and soft palate
Treatment:      24.7.01 serial biopsies
      8-10.01 - 3 x ProMACE CytaBOM (CR)
      10.11 .01 - Radical radiotherapy (50 Gy in 25 fractions)
      Since 3.12.01 - 1 /3 of ProMACE CytaBOM
Karli reattended my clinic today together with her mother, following completion of her radiotherapy. Overall I am very pleased to see that the majority of radiotherapy associated side-effects have completely settled. The facial oedema and erythema has nearly completely subsided, although the skin still remains slightly dry and hyper-pigmented. There are currently no signs of any infection or discharge, although Karli reports that her taste has not yet recovered.
On clinical examination there are no abnormalities, specifically no evidence of any palpable lymphadenopathy, and at the moment clinically remains in complete remission.
I have given Karli another opportunity to discuss some potentially unanswered questions arising from her previous radiotherapy and we had some discussion with respect to some of the potential late sequelae related to this. Clearly, she needs to continue with good oral care in order to prevent early tooth decay, as well as needing close monitoring with respect to her thyroid function in the years to come.
At the moment the only unpleasant side-effect of the overall treatment is related to general fatigue and some indigestion. She is due to be readmitted for her next cycle of chemotherapy tomorrow, and I have made no further arrangements for Karli to reattend my clinic, but pointed out that they could either contact me at any time in the future at short notice, or when attending follow-up clinics here. I anticipate that she will remain under the care of Professor Pinkerton for follow up
Episode type: New event, Free text: 2 more chemo sessions to go. very tired
Episode type: New event, Free text: bilateral red eyes with discharge
Free text: for Ametop gel

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Taj:\\Karli came to clinic on 3 d December three weeks after completion of her radiotherapy. She was very well in herself, and the radiation induced dermatitis around her nose and neck was much improved. Her clinical examination was entirely normal.
The plan is to start her chemotherapy which will consist of a further three courses of ProMACE CytaBOM on Thursday 6 ' December. This will be accompanied by a lumbar puncture with intrathecal Methotrexate. Tablet Prednisolone will be given for ten days and then tapered over a four day period

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Taylor:\\  Diagnosis: NK T-cell lymphoma arising from the mucosa of the right lower nostril. Treatment: 23.8.01: ProMACE CytaBOM chemotherapy x3 cycles. 15.10.01 to 19.1 1 .01 : Radical radiotherapy to the nose and neck.
This 17-year old girl has now completed a course of radical radiotherapy for natural killer cell T-cell lymphoma arising from the nose. She was initially treated with 3 cycles of chemotherapy and had an excellent response to this treatment. The site of primary disease was treated with a total dose of 50 Gy in 25 fractions using a complex 3-field plan between 15.10.01 and 19.1 1.01 using 6MV photons. The neck was treated using a standard anterior split neck technique to 50 Gy in 25 fractions over the same time period. She tolerated the radiotherapy treatment extremely well. There was the expected erythema of the skin around the nose and neck. She has been prescribed Diprobase cream to help relieve this but she is aware that the erythema will take up to 2 weeks before it starts to settle. She also developed some soreness inside her throat for which she is taking soluble paracetamol and her nose generally feels blocked. Throughout the treatment she has lost her appetite and has lost a little bit of weight although at the last recording it was fairly static at 46.4 kg. She is being encouraged to eat and drink little and often.
Once the acute reaction has settled, she will then proceed to a further 3 cycles of chemotherapy which will complete her treatment. I have arranged a further appointment in the radiotherapy follow up clinic for 4 weeks time to ensure that the acute reaction has settled appropriately
Episode type: New event, Free text: confusion over script as fucidin issued but from July. will not take this

resource.comment:
Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Saran:\\Diagnosis: NK/T-cell lymphoma of the nose (high grade) Treatment: 24.7.01 serial biopsies.
Since 23.8.01 ProMACE CytaBOM chemotherapy.
Thank you very much for asking me to see Karli for consideration of radical radiotherapy. I have already taken the opportunity while Karli was an inpatient over the last few days to broadly outline the reasons and most likely associated side-effects of a course of radical radiotherapy both to her and her mother who attended today' s consultation. I also took the opportunity to discuss her particular radiotherapy requirements with Dr Yau at Hong Kong University, who usually works together with Professor Kwong, and has significant experience in this area. He sent his protocol which I will use when planning her radiotherapy.
It appeared that since the initial serial biopsy there has been some progression of disease both in the primary area around her nose, as well as potentially in the soft palate. Furthermore, at our last joint consultation last week at the start of chemotherapy there was a clinical palpable lymph node within her right jugulo-digastric angle which measured approximately IYz x I cm. Since initiating chemotherapy there has already been a significant reduction in the size of this previously highly suspicious lymph node, and I could only feel an approximately .5 x .8 mm soft mobile lymph node in this location. Furthermore, repeat imaging which will serve as a base-line for my radiotherapy planning, did not reveal any evidence of bony destruction. Furthermore, the MRI of her neck performed the same day (28' April) revealed only very small nodes bilaterally in the neck without convincing evidence of cervical lymphadenopathy.
On this background I have discussed with her the acute and intermittent and long-term sideeffects of a radical course of radiotherapy consisting of 50 Gy in 25 fractions over five weeks to the nose part of the sinuses, soft palate and bilateral lymph nodes of her neck. I explained to her that in a specific situation I have to ensure that there were will an adequate dose going to the area of the nose with the likelihood of significant skin reaction and rhinitis. 
  Furthermore, she is likely to suffer from a marked skin rash, dysphasia, mucositis, reduction of saliva, as well as a potential loss of taste. Given that the dose is limited to 50 Gy as suggested by Dr Yau, I would anticipate that all of these side-effects will not be permanent, although there is a small risk that she may develop a slightly dryer mouth in the future. As late sequelae I mentioned to her the significant risk of tooth decay, as well as hypothyroidism. Furthermore, I pointed out that radiotherapy in her age group has a risk of second malignancies, which I quoted to be in the range of I-3% over the next 10-20 years.
Karli consented today to proceed with radiotherapy as suggested, and I have already made the necessary arrangements for her to undergo radiotherapy planning with her first appointment being on 31st August for mould room assessment. I anticipated that the start of radiotherapy will be following completion of three cycles of ProMACE CytaBOM with haematological recovery anticipated for 292' October.
I will of course keep you informed of her future progress
Episode type: New event, Free text: chat with mum.  Karli had first chemo this week

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Ruth Hindmarch:\\ The above young lady has been referred to the Community Children's Nursing Team following her recent diagnosis with  natural killer' T cell lymphoma. Throughout Karli's planned care she will be seen by the Community Children's Nursing Team for weekly blood counts, intravenous chemotherapy, as prescribed by the Royal Marsden Hospital, and support The results of all blood tests carried out by the community nurse will always be followed up on the same day and communicated to the Royal Marsden Hospital. However, in some circumstances East Surrey Hospital laboratory have contacted the GP when concerned about a result - should this happen please feel free to contact us on the pager number above.
Karli's shared care is yet to be discussed with Dr Khoobarry, Crawley Hospital although the majority of her treatment will be at the Royal Marsden Hospital. Should Karli be admitted with febrile neutropaenia, the Community Children's Nursing Team is able to offer home IV antibiotics, although children are not generally discharged home for that care until they have remained apyrexial for at least 48-72 hours.   
1 would be most grateful if you could prescribe the following items on a repeat prescription for maintenance of Karli's ports-cath that was recently inserted
1      0.9% SODIUM CHLORIDE FOR IV USE (PLASTIC SAFETY AMPOULES) X 4 BOXES OF 20 X IOMLS
HEPARINISED SALINE 100 UNITSIMML FOR IV USE X 4 BOXES OF 10 X 2MLS VIALS
*      AMETOP LOCAL ANAESTHETIC CREAM 1.5 GRAM TUBE X 6 TUBES
PINK CHLORHEXIDINE GL UCONATE 0.5 % IN & 70% v/v IMS x 1 bottle of 500mls
Finally, may I take this opportunity to say how much all families with children who have cancer continue to value the support they get from their GP.
Please do not hesitate to contact me should you require further information

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Dr Mary Taj:  \\Karli and her parents came to clinic today for staging of her lymphoma. I was able to confirm the diagnosis which is indeed NK/T-cell lymphoma of the nasal type previously known as lethal mid-line granuloma. Morphologically it is a high grade lymphoma with a lot of necrosis. Immunophenotypically the biopsy showed atypical lymphoid cells positive for CD3 (cytoplasmic) positive for CD56 (NK marker) and T1 A-I positive but negative for CD20 and CD8. The proliferation fraction was over 90% with MIB-1 antibody. In situ hybridisation for E13V related antigen was positive. I explained to Karli and her parents that while this tumour is very rare in the Western population, it is not uncommon in the far East where it has been described among the adult population. Patients younger than 35 years of age with stage I disease and those without 'B' symptoms have a relatively good prognosis. Patients with disseminated phase do badly even with aggressive treatment. As such our plan is to follow the protocol being used by Professor Kwong at Hong Kong University. This involves three courses of ProMACE CytaBOM followed by 45-50 Gy involved field radiotherapy, followed by another three courses of chemotherapy. After the first three courses our plan is to re-assess her with scans and repeat biopsy. If there is a delayed or inadequate response an autologous transplant with C13V conditioning is recommended. With the above protocol patients with stage I localised disease have a 60-70% chance of cure. The disease does not generally spread to the CNS but disseminates locally eventually spreading to distant lymph nodes, liver, spleen, lungs and bone marrow.
The plan is for Karli to have a CT scan of her chest/abdomen and a bone scan on 21st August, followed by an echocardiogram and lung function tests at St George's Hospital on 22nd August. We will then perform a lumbar puncture with intrathecal Methotrexate, bone marrow aspirate and trephine and insertion of a portacath on 23 d August and then admit her for chemotherapy.
Chemotherapy will consist of Cyclophosphamide, Adriamycin and Etoposide on day I with oral Prednisolone for 14 days, this is followed by Cytarabine, Bleomycin, Methotrexate with folinic acid rescue on day 8. The whole cycle is then repeated on count recovery.
After the initial shock Karli and her parents seemed relieved that we had a diagnosis and a treatment option that had a reasonable chance of cure. They are aware of the side-effects of the drugs and the fact that it is a very aggressive tumour that has to be treated with intensive chemotherapy and radiotherapy. I have also discussed the possibility of an autologous transplant in the future.
Since this tumour is EBV driven I am exploring the possibility of doing quantitative RT-PCR' s serially as a way of monitoring disease activity. We will also a sample of Karli's bone marrow trephine to Dr Dougan at The University College in London for in situ hybridisation studies for EBV

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Mr J D Brookes Consultant Otolaryngologist:\\Karli came to clinic on 13th August 2001, referred to the Marsden by Mr Brookes, ConsultantOtolaryngologist at Gatwick Park Hospital. She is a 17-year old girl who first started having problems about 18 months ago. At that time she complained of a blockage of the right side of her nose. She was referred to Epsom Hospital and treated with a nasal spray and antibiotics. It was thought there was thickening of the nasal mucosa, which might need to be cauterised. Subsequently she developed swelling of her left eye and was referred to Mr Brookes at Gatwick Park Hospital. Over this time she developed a gradually increasing swelling of the right side of her nose. Initially there was just a nodule inside her nose but over the past 3-4 months she has developed a crusted lesion covering the right anterior naves and right side of her upper lip. She has had multiple local infections including a staphylococcus infection and has had several courses of antibiotics over the last 2 months. In February of this year she had a CT scan of her sinuses which showed a right maxillary mucocoele and a mucocoele of her right ethmoid sinuses. There was no bony erosion and the swelling seemed to be localised to her anterior naves and inferior turbinate. The scan seemed to confirm a diagnosis of sinusitis and for a time she improved with antibiotics. There is no history of headache, vomiting or fever. There is, however, a history of tiredness and fatigue.
About 6 weeks ago she developed an ulcer on her hard palate which has gradually increased in size. It is not painful but hurts when she eats spicy food. On 24.7.01 she had multiple biopsies taken from her nasal lesion and also had a biopsy at the site of the ulcer on her hard palate. Following this she had an MRI of her head done on 30.7.01 .
On examination she has a dark brown, crusted, rounded lesion 2 x 2 cm outside her right nostril, almost completely blocking the right side of her nose. The right side of her nose seems swollen. Examination of her mouth shows a high arched palate with a 1 x 1.5 cm irregular ulcer on the left side. Palpation showed a normal firm palate with no undue tenderness and no mass palpable. Her liver and spleen were normal and there were no palpable lymph nodes. Examination of her fundi was normal and both her ears were fine. Her weight was 44 kg, height 156.4 cm and blood pressure 126/66.
The provisional diagnosis from Karli's biopsy is a Nk/T-cell lymphoma of nasal type. However, since her history is so unusual, the plan is fof her biopsy to be reviewed by Dr Andy Wotherspoon. Review of her CT and MRI scans shows a mass present on the right lower nostril that enhances on contrast, extending into the inferior turbinate. There is no bony erosion but some destruction of ethmoid air cells, probably because of the formation of a mucocoele. A mucocoele is also present in her right maxillary sinus. There is no obvious infiltration of her septum or hard palate. On balance, the scan results were more in keeping with a diagnosis of infection/inflammation rather than a tumour.
Karli's chest x-ray was entirely normal. Baseline bloods have been done, the results of which are still awaited. I will call Karli and her parents as soon as I have a firm diagnosis, when we can discuss treatment

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Mr Brookes:\\I reviewed Karli in my clinic today. Although the swelling in her nose has gone down slightly she is now complaining of soreness in the roof of her mouth and on examination there is an obvious inflamed area here. I am now quite concerned that there might be some underlying osteomyelitis here or possibly even a low grade malignant process and I have therefore arranged for her to come in to have biopsies performed within the next few days.
I will let you know how we get on

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: J. D. Brookes:  \\I reviewed Karli Broadbent in my clinic today. I am pleased to report the Staphylococcal infection in the right nasal vestibule is finally beginning to settle. The swelling in her nose is dramatically improved. She still has an active Staphylococcal vestibulitis however and I have arranged for her to continue the Augmentin with the Fucidin cream for the next 2 weeks and I will review her again.
I will let you know how we get on

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Mr Brookes:\\I reviewed Karli in my clinic today. Her Staphylococcal vestibulitis in her right nose is settling, albeit slowly. I swabbed the nose again today and renewed her Augmentin and gave her some Fucidin ointment for her nasal vestibule and will review her again in 2 weeks time. I will let you know how we get on

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: J. D. Brookes:  \\I reviewed Karli Broadbent in my clinic today. As I am sure you are aware she saw my colleague Mr Warrington whilst I was on leave. This poor young lady has had a Staphylococcal vestibulitis which is probably an infection of the hair follicle within the right nasal vestibule and unrelated to her previous sinusitis. After a week of Erythromycin Karli's nose has improved a little but was still quite dramatic. She has now had 2 further days of Erythromycin which had no altered the appearance much. She is still showing typical signs of Staphylococcal infection and I have therefore changed her antibiotics to Augmentin having swabbed her nose. I will review her in a weeks time. I will let you know how we get on

Episode type: Continuing, Free text: Mr J D Brookes:  \\Thank you for asking me to see this young lady with a quite severe soft tissue infection of the right nasal vestibule.
It all started some three weeks ago and in spite of the swab showing Staphylococcus aureus sensitive to flucloxacillin and erythromycin the patient did not respond to ten days worth of flucloxacillin. However she seems to be responding quite well to erythromycin even though she has only been on it for three days.
I carried out a fibre-optic nasoendoscopy in order to ascertain that there is no lesion growing in right nasal cavity causing the swelling on the right hand side of the nose. The right nasal cavity looks normal as does indeed the nasopharynx. I have said to Karli that she must continue on the erythromycin and to also use the antiseptic ointment that you prescribed for her. If when the seven day course of erythromycin is finished the infection has not yet settled down, I would suggest that she continues the erythromycin for a further three to five days, but at that point I would repeat the nasal swab in order to find out whether the bacteriology or the sensitivities have changed. Karli will see Mr Brookes if she continues to have problems
Free text: No pathogens isolated (No infection shown)
Episode type: Continuing, Free text: R nostril, needs to continue with erythromycin, I wonder whether this could be a granulomatous condition. Consider paed referral if it doesn't get better
